I. INTRODUCTION
1. The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) for Policy Research and Capacity
Building to Strengthen Rural Economies in the Southwest Region of the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) will support the preparation of a comprehensive study recommending the policies 
needed to build a firm foundation of labor income opportunities to protect and improve the lives 
of the rural low-income population in the southwest region of the PRC.1 Paying particular attention 
to Guizhou province, the TA will support the preparation of policy recommendations to strengthen 
both the agriculture and non-agriculture sectors that have the most impact in ensuring labor 
income opportunities for the rural low-income population. The TA will help improve the lives of the 
low-income population and include them in the development process by strengthening economic 
activities in the southwestern region of the PRC. 
2. The TA is consistent with the overarching goal of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)
country partnership strategy, 2021–2025 for the PRC, which supports the Government of the
PRC’s efforts to achieve high-quality, green development and notes that gains from rapid growth
have not been shared evenly in the PRC and that "tackling inequality of income and opportunity
requires policy actions to reduce environmental, social, and economic disparities between regions,
and between rural and urban areas."2
II. ISSUES
3. While the PRC has made tremendous progress in reducing poverty—approximately 850
million people have risen out of absolute poverty in the last four decades—rapid growth has also
given rise to new concerns, including social inequality. The country announced in February 2021
that it had eradicated absolute poverty.3 However, gains from rapid growth have not been shared
evenly, with the PRC’s Gini coefficient remaining at a relatively high level—above 0.46—from
2014–2019.4 The Fifth Plenary Session of the 19th Central Committee of the Communist Party of
China  prioritized  high-quality  development  by  establishing  support  mechanisms  for
underdeveloped areas, promoting the sustainable development of industries with local features,
and helping key rural counties emerge from poverty.
4. Guizhou is one of the lower income provinces in the PRC. In 2019, its gross domestic
product per capita was CNY46,433, or 65.8% of the PRC average (CNY70,581).5 In 2017, its
poverty rate of 7.75% was more than double the national rate of 3.10%.6 In support of the national
government’s innovative approach of inclusive development and focus on rural revitalization, the
Guizhou provincial government identified and started developing key rural industries that have 
strong potential to create local labor income opportunities, such as ecological poultry, farming, 
tea, edible fungus cultivation, Chinese medicinal herb cultivation, and tourism. The Guizhou 
provincial government also identified “Eight Elements” for the promotion of a rural industrial
revolution: selection of industries, training of farmers, provision of technical services, fund raising,

2021.

2 
organization methods, integration of production and sales, strengthening links across various 
interests, and the Communist Party of China’s structure at the grassroots level. 7
5. Despite these efforts, further development is needed, particularly in rural areas where
resource  utilization  is  limited.  Strengthening  rural  economies  to  ensure  local  labor  income
opportunities for the rural low-income population in the southwest PRC, including in the Guizhou
province, is a key concern. Policies are needed to build a firm foundation of local labor income
opportunities to protect and improve the lives of the rural low-income population. There is also a
need to understand how the changing national and global contexts affect the local economy. This
has become even more important following the PRC’s achievement of its goal of absolute poverty 
eradication in 2020, which saw low-income households starting to seek more stable and higher 
labor income streams. Investigating the various factors of production in urban and rural areas, 
strengthening farm and nonfarm income streams, reducing labor income gaps within the region, 
and promoting a coordinated and new regional development approach to provide sustainable 
labor income opportunities are needed. It is also important to identify obstacles and potential 
growth paths for local rural labor income opportunities in this region. 
6. The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and will contribute to addressing vulnerable
populations and reducing inequalities within the PRC, promoting rural development and food 
security, and strengthening governance and institutional capacity.8 The TA also follows the 
recommendations from the final review of the country partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for the
PRC, which recognized that “implementing loan projects at lower levels of government helps 
address local institutional and capacity gaps, which are often the main constraints on achieving 
national development goals.”9
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Impact and Outcome
7. The TA is aligned with the following impact: green, high-quality development achieved,
especially across counties in the southwest region of the PRC.10 The TA will have the following
outcome: strategies and policies to strengthen agriculture and nonagriculture sectors in the
southwest region improved.11 The TA will support a study that is expected to better inform the
Guizhou  provincial  government  on  policies  that  improve  production  conditions,  strengthen
capacity development, and enhance labor income opportunities. By the end of the TA, at least
one policy recommendation or innovation measure arising from the TA is expected to be adopted
and implemented by multiple stakeholders in Guizhou. The study is also expected to lead to at
least  one  stakeholder  in  the  southwest  region,  from  either  the  agriculture  sector  or  a
nonagriculture sector, to adopt an innovative measure to promote sustainability of its operation
and create labor income opportunities for the rural low-income population.
7  In July 2019, the Guizhou provincial government issued Opinions on Deepening the Rural Industrial Revolution to 
Strive for the Overall Success in the Fight against Poverty, proposing “Eight Elements” for the development of rural 
industries. 
8  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
9  Independent Evaluation Department. 2020. Validation of the Country Partnership Strategy Final Review: People’s 
Republic of China, 2016–2020. Manila: ADB.
10 Government of the PRC. 2021. The Outline of the Fourteenth Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social 
Development and the Long-range Objectives through the Year 2035. Beijing. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B. Outputs, Methods, and Activities
8. Output  1:  Study  on  strengthening  rural  economies  that  ensures labor income
opportunities of the rural low-income population in the southwest People's Republic of
China completed. The TA will first conduct a stock-taking exercise of the targeted sectors,  such
as ecological poultry, farming, tea, edible fungus cultivation, Chinese medicinal herb cultivation,
and  tourism,  through  a  comprehensive  review  of  the  existing  policy  research  and
recommendations relevant to the region and assess the progress and challenges in implementing
these. Based on this exercise, the TA will produce a comprehensive study analyzing (i) the
challenges surrounding existing economic foundations, including labor market and land policies,
investments in physical infrastructure, employment services, the role of financial institutions, and
links with vocational education and income transfers; (ii) the conditions to support efficient flows
of production factors between urban and rural areas, including tax incentives and pilot investment
opportunities; (iii) the approaches to building sustainable green economies through institutional
and policy reforms; and (iv) the policy recommendations and steps to providing labor income
opportunities  to  rural  low-income  households.  A  section  on  gender-specific  issues  in  the
southwest  region  of  the  PRC  will  also  be  included.  This  could  cover  female  labor  force
participation in the agriculture sector, levels of skills of the female labor force in the sector, and
barriers and opportunities for reskilling and capacity building of women in the agriculture sector.
The study will also include at least one case study of a city in Guizhou province, such as Bijie,
Liupanshui, and Tongren—which could serve as a demonstration case that can be replicated in
other cities in the PRC, particularly in the southwest region, and in other ADB developing member 
countries. 
9. The study will align with recommendations from past ADB TA projects and projects in
Guizhou province, including the study supported by the TA on Provincial Development Strategies
for Chongqing Municipality and Guizhou Province, which reviewed economic development and
the  industrialization  strategy  in  Guizhou;12 and  the  results-based  lending  for  the  Guizhou
Vocational  Education  Development  Program,  which  looked  at  strengthening  technical  and
vocational education and training in the province.13 The study also builds on previous studies
supported by ADB’s regional TA for Supporting Strategic Knowledge Products and Research
Networking,14 such as the Poverty Reduction and Development: National Strategies and a Case 
Study of ADB-Funded Pilot Project in Nayong County in Guizhou Province, People’s Republic of 
China, which shows how national poverty reduction strategies and local projects contribute 
successfully to poverty reduction and development.15  
10. While the primary means of dissemination of the study and policy recommendations is
through digital publication and workshops, the TA will support printing of publication, if a Chinese
version of the study is needed for distribution to local government officials and local enterprise
owners to better disseminate the results of the study.
11. Output  2:  Policy  advice  on  strengthening  rural  economies  that  ensures  labor
income  opportunities  of  the  rural  low-income  population  in  the  southwest  People's

Province. Manila. 
13 ADB. 2016. Results-Based Lending to the People’s Republic of China for the Guizhou Vocational Education
Development Program. Manila (Loan 3352-PRC). 
14 ADB. 2007. Supporting Strategic Knowledge Products and Research Networking. Manila. 
15 N. Sapkota et al. 2017. Poverty Reduction and Development: National Strategies and a Case Study of ADB-Funded

4 
Republic of China finalized. The TA will distill actionable policy recommendations from the 
studies completed under output 1, and provide specific policy advice on strengthening the rural 
economies through the channels identified in the studies. Policy notes will be produced and 
policies recommended to support rural economies in the region. These works will be disseminated 
at training workshops for consideration of the Guizhou provincial government and other local 
government units in the southwest region of the PRC.  
12. Output 3: Understanding of local government officials and managers of business
enterprises on the approaches to strengthen local economies enhanced. The TA will support
technical workshops and dialogue with the provincial government and managers of business
enterprises to help strengthen the understanding of environmentally sustainable, value-adding
practices in managing rural enterprises. At least 30 government and industry officials, at least 30%
of which are female, are expected to attend these workshops and training. Evaluation and
feedback forms will be used after the workshops and training. Follow-up surveys and dialogue
with enterprise managers will be held to assess if there was increased understanding of issues
affecting operations in the targeted rural areas. At least one stakeholder—a village leader, an
enterprise, a collective agriculture unit, or a local government unit—is expected to adopt at least
one of the innovative approaches or policy recommendations identified by the study, which will
lead to sustainable operations. The TA assumes that enterprises, farmers, and local government
officials are open to adopting innovative approaches, and there will be no changes in national or
local government priorities which could hinder the achievement of this indicator during the TA
implementation period. A follow-up survey will also be undertaken with participants of workshops
and trainings 6 months and 1 year after the study, workshops, and training sessions to gauge the
level of adoption of study recommendations. The adoption of policy recommendations is expected
to  help  strengthen  enterprises  and  enable  them  to  better  contribute  to  green,  high-quality
development.
C. Cost and Financing
13. The TA is estimated to cost $330,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources).16
14. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of information and data
support, counterpart staff, office supplies, conference and training venues, secretarial assistance,
and other in-kind contributions. The value of the government contribution is estimated to account
for 10% of the total ADB contribution.
D. Implementation Arrangements
15. ADB will administer the TA. The executing agency—the Office of the Director General of
the East Asia Department—in coordination with the Guizhou Foreign Capital Project Management
Center of Guizhou Province Poverty Reduction and Development Office will select, supervise,
and evaluate consultants; oversee the completion and publication of knowledge products; and
provide staff as resource persons in the knowledge and capacity development activities, as
necessary.  The  implementing  agency—the Project  Division  of the Guizhou  Foreign  Capital
Project Management Center of Guizhou Province Poverty Reduction and Development Office—
will supervise the conduct of the research study and other related studies, organize technical
workshops, and in coordination with the Office of the Director General of the East Asia Department,
make necessary arrangements for implementing TA components.

IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
18. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Policy Research and Capacity Building to
Strengthen Rural Economies in the Southwest Region of the People’s Republic of China, and
hereby reports this action to the Board.
